LOANE CHOSEN AS
TAU BETA PI HEAD
Edward S. Loane was elected president of Tau Beta Pi
and H. Ridgely Warfield, Jr.,
vice-president at a banquet
held by that organization last
week at the Hopkins Club.
The other officers chosen at
this meeting were: Alfred
Banos, recording secretary;
James W. Joyce, corresponding secretary, and Edward
Skipper, treasurer. Larkin
Farinholt was appointed delegate to the national-convention
of Tau Beta Pi, which will be
held next fall at Columbus,
Ohio, and A. E. Vivell, first
alternate.

MUD, OR THE ADVICE OF' A TOAD
Entered as second-class matter December 3, 1909, at the Postoffice at
Baltimore, Md., under Act of Congress, November 3, 1879.

One moon-lit summer evening I walked a lonely road;
My one uncouth companion was a fascinating toad,
And the dumb desire to talk to me was shining in his eyes,
So I bravely stopped and questioned him, though I knew it wasn't

Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns

"There is mud in all the world to-night," most suddenly he
croaked;
This sudden speech so startled me I gasped, and nearly choked.
"There's mud in this, and mud in that, and mud in every road,
And the one way to endure it is—pretend that you're a toad."

I 1 East Lexington Street. We have
placed many Hopkins graduates.

There was mud so soft and sloppy that it crept up to my waist;—
My guide kicked up a lively spray, which had a horrid taste— •
Then finally the old toad paused in a very -messy spot
\Vith, "You needs must pause and roll in this, if you feel distaste or not."

So saying, he began to roll, and to see a rolling toad
Was so extremely funny that I doubled up and crowed
And chortled with great merriment, till he ceased and looked at
me,
Remarking with a blasting look, "What's the joke; I fail to see."

Printed by The Read-Taylor Press, South and Lombard Streets

FREEDOM OF THE PRESS?
. Is there really such a thing as -freedom of the press" in
college journalism? Last Tuesday we mentioned the most obvious policies which a college paper can follow in its editorial
column, mentioning in particular the difficulties of following a
definite policy on a small campus.
The most serious of these was the almost inevitable injection
of the personal element into the interpretation of editorials. Ni
matter how unbiased the editor attempts to be, he finds that the
majority of his readers, being people whom he knows personally,
are ready to take issue with him upon any point which piques them
in an intimate way. It seems nearly impossible to comment upon
current campus topics without the subjects of the comments experiencing a sort of wounded dignity.
As a frank example, anything that should have been said in
these columns concerning the recent Student Council election
would have been interpreted as derogatory towards one or more
of the candidates. And this despite any protestations we should
have made to the contrary.
Perhaps, as we said Tuesday, it is undesirable that the campus
paper should act, in any sense of the word, as a critic. Though
we seriously doubt this fact, we reiterate our request for expressions of opinion by our readers. Let us know what you think.

A sense of my ingratitude come.pouring thru my soul,
So I murmured, "Please forgive me," and then / began to- roll.
In a second it was clear to me that even mud has charm,
For life is but a pool of mud, and rolling brings no harm.
I saw the earthly wisdom of my small four-legged friend,
Who observed that I'd been clean before, and soon my ways must
mend.
One cannot live without it ; without it one must die;—
Mud out of mud arisen and under mud to lie.

So I gloried in the sordidness of life's pervading dirt;
I rolled around and wallowed, till my frame began to hurt.
Then I looked for my omniscient friend, but found that he had
gone,
And saw, appearing o'er the trees, the rosy glowing dawn.
Now take this bit of knowledge; masticate it like a cud:
There's nothing in this world of ours so known and thrown a,
mud. . .
And that's not last sweet evening I walked that lonely road,
But T swear I've never been again accosted by a toad.

"0 most sagacious froggie, why do you walk with me?
For a silent, moody human must be dismal company.
It's not the first sweet evening that I've walked this lonely road
But I swear I've never been before accosted by a toad."

Then up he jumped and I arose and followed in his wake;
He left the path and hopped straightway into the roadside brake.
We wallowed and we waded thru a world composed of mud
Till Life, and Love, and Everything, seemed just a slimy flood.

With the exception of the Barnstormers' annual farce, the
only dramatic offerings on the campus are those of the Homewood Playshop, an activity not actively supported by undergraduates probably because the student activities card does not admit
the bearer to its productions. Despite the lack of undergraduate
interest, however, the Playshop has just completed what is perhaps the best season in its history. It presented John Van Druten's "The Round Trip", with the author himself playing the
. leading role. "The Great. Galeoto," the most recent offering, so
successful that it was taken over to the Eastern Shore to delight
the natives.
It seems rather deplorable that most of the work of the Playshop should be carried on by outsiders. Though one or two wellknown undergraduate actors took leading parts in "The Great
Galeoto", the number of students present at the performances
was comparatively small. Perhaps it is best that the organization is called the "Homewood" Playshop and not the "Hopkins"
Playshop.

Bill" was called on for a "speech."
In his "speech," Coach Schmeisser
told the Jay stickmen just why they
had come out on top and what factors, aside from the coaching, had
contributed to their long string of
victories. He ended by paying a
great tribute to Robinson, in which
he said he had placed Robinson on
his list of super-players of all times.
Various members of the team
gave short talks, most of which
were humorous, and the banquet
ended with the recommendation of
fourteen of the players and
Manager Bowling for
major
"H's". Those recommended for letters were Finn, Liebensperger, Mallonee, Roy, Dotterweich, Boynton,
Lang, Farinholt, Morrill, Robinson,
Biddison, Logan, Kegan, Eagan,
and Bowling.

LOANE CHOSEN AS
TAU BETA PI HEAD
Edward S. Loane was elected president of Tau Beta Pi
and H. Ridgely Warfield, Jr.,
vice-president at a banquet
held by that organization last
week at the Hopkins Club.
The other officers chosen at
this meeting were: Alfred
Banos, recording secretary;
James W. Joyce, corresponding secretary, and Edward
Skipper, treasurer. Larkin
Farinholt was appointed delegate to the national-convention
of Tau Beta Pi, which will be
held next fall at Columbus,
Ohio, and A. E. Vivell, first
alternate.

MUD, OR THE ADVICE OF' A TOAD
Entered as second-class matter December 3, 1909, at the Postoffice at
Baltimore, Md., under Act of Congress, November 3, 1879.

One moon-lit summer evening I walked a lonely road;
My one uncouth companion was a fascinating toad,
And the dumb desire to talk to me was shining in his eyes,
So I bravely stopped and questioned him, though I knew it wasn't

"There is mud in all the world to-night," most suddenly he
croaked;
This sudden speech so startled me I gasped, and nearly choked.
"There's mud in this, and mud in that, and mud in every road,
And the one way to endure it is—pretend that you're a toad."

placed many Hopkins graduates.

There was mud so soft and sloppy that it crept up to my waist;—
My guide kicked up a lively spray, which had a horrid taste— •
Then finally the old toad paused in a very -messy spot
\Vith, "You needs must pause and roll in this, if you feel distaste or not."

So saying, he began to roll, and to see a rolling toad
Was so extremely funny that I doubled up and crowed
And chortled with great merriment, till he ceased and looked at
me,
Remarking with a blasting look, "What's the joke; I fail to see."

FREEDOM OF THE PRESS?
. Is there really such a thing as -freedom of the press" in
college journalism? Last Tuesday we mentioned the most obvious policies which a college paper can follow in its editorial
column, mentioning in particular the difficulties of following a
definite policy on a small campus.
The most serious of these was the almost inevitable injection
of the personal element into the interpretation of editorials. Ni
matter how unbiased the editor attempts to be, he finds that the
majority of his readers, being people whom he knows personally,
are ready to take issue with him upon any point which piques them
in an intimate way. It seems nearly impossible to comment upon
current campus topics without the subjects of the comments experiencing a sort of wounded dignity.
As a frank example, anything that should have been said in
these columns concerning the recent Student Council election
would have been interpreted as derogatory towards one or more
of the candidates. And this despite any protestations we should
have made to the contrary.
Perhaps, as we said Tuesday, it is undesirable that the campus
paper should act, in any sense of the word, as a critic. Though
we seriously doubt this fact, we reiterate our request for expressions of opinion by our readers. Let us know what you think.

A sense of my ingratitude come.pouring thru my soul,
So I murmured, "Please forgive me," and then / began to- roll.
In a second it was clear to me that even mud has charm,
For life is but a pool of mud, and rolling brings no harm.
I saw the earthly wisdom of my small four-legged friend,
Who observed that I'd been clean before, and soon my ways must
mend.
One cannot live without it ; without it one must die;—
Mud out of mud arisen and under mud to lie.

So I gloried in the sordidness of life's pervading dirt;
I rolled around and wallowed, till my frame began to hurt.
Then I looked for my omniscient friend, but found that he had
gone,
And saw, appearing o'er the trees, the rosy glowing dawn.
Now take this bit of knowledge; masticate it like a cud:
There's nothing in this world of ours so known and thrown a,
mud. . .
And that's not last sweet evening I walked that lonely road,
But T swear I've never been again accosted by a toad.

"0 most sagacious froggie, why do you walk with me?
For a silent, moody human must be dismal company.
It's not the first sweet evening that I've walked this lonely road
But I swear I've never been before accosted by a toad."

Then up he jumped and I arose and followed in his wake;
He left the path and hopped straightway into the roadside brake.
We wallowed and we waded thru a world composed of mud
Till Life, and Love, and Everything, seemed just a slimy flood.

With the exception of the Barnstormers' annual farce, the
only dramatic offerings on the campus are those of the Homewood Playshop, an activity not actively supported by undergraduates probably because the student activities card does not admit
the bearer to its productions. Despite the lack of undergraduate
interest, however, the Playshop has just completed what is perhaps the best season in its history. It presented John Van Druten's "The Round Trip", with the author himself playing the
. leading role. "The Great. Galeoto," the most recent offering, so
successful that it was taken over to the Eastern Shore to delight
the natives.
It seems rather deplorable that most of the work of the Playshop should be carried on by outsiders. Though one or two wellknown undergraduate actors took leading parts in "The Great
Galeoto", the number of students present at the performances
was comparatively small. Perhaps it is best that the organization is called the "Homewood" Playshop and not the "Hopkins"
Playshop.

Bill" was called on for a "speech."
In his "speech," Coach Schmeisser
told the Jay stickmen just why they
had come out on top and what factors, aside from the coaching, had
contributed to their long string of
victories. He ended by paying a
great tribute to Robinson, in which
he said he had placed Robinson on
his list of super-players of all times.
Various members of the team
gave short talks, most of which
were humorous, and the banquet
ended with the recommendation of
fourteen of the players and
Manager Bowling for
major
"H's". Those recommended for letters were Finn, Liebensperger, Mallonee, Roy, Dotterweich, Boynton,
Lang, Farinholt, Morrill, Robinson,
Biddison, Logan, Kegan, Eagan,
and Bowling.
